conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, and their size and position depend on the light source's position relative to the object and surface.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are currently cast on the ground by the objects above the slabs.
Moving the light source backward increases the distance between the light source and the objects, affecting both the position and size of the shadows.
As the light source moves backward, the angle of light relative to the objects decreases, causing the shadows to shift backward, away from the objects.
With the light source moving backward, the shadows will become longer due to the increased distance between the light source and the objects.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will move backward, away from the objects.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will become longer.
When the light source moves backward above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and become longer.
